head.title: Falling Ice Injures Four Women in Three Incidents

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey
Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Falling Ice Injures Four Women in Three Incidents
hedline.hl2: Falling Ice Injures Four Women in Three Incidents

block.p: Falling ice around the metropolitan area injured at least four people yesterday, prompting the authorities to temporarily shut down roads and streets to remove potential hazards, police and fire officials said.
None of the injured -- two pedestrians in New York City and two people in a vehicle in New Jersey -- were critically hurt, but three were hospitalized.

Falling ice around the metropolitan area injured at least four people yesterday, prompting the authorities to temporarily shut down roads and streets to remove potential hazards, police and fire officials said.

Falling ice around the metropolitan area injured at least four people yesterday, prompting the authorities to temporarily shut down roads and streets to remove potential hazards, police and fire officials said.
None of the injured -- two pedestrians in New York City and two people in a vehicle in New Jersey -- were critically hurt, but three were hospitalized.

The two pedestrians were struck in separate incidents in Manhattan. A 25-year-old woman was hit by falling ice near the corner of Lexington Avenue and East 89th Street shortly after 2 p.m. and was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital, the Fire Department said.

Another woman walking on West 43rd Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues was hit shortly before 6 p.m. in front of the New York Times building, the police said. She was treated at the scene, but the police shut down 43rd Street between the two avenues for about half an hour last evening as maintenance crews at The Times pushed ice off the roof.
In New Jersey, two women in a sport utility vehicle on Raymond Boulevard in Newark were struck by a large piece of ice that fell from the Pulaski Skyway, the authorities said.
The driver, Flordaliz Mauricio, 28, and her passenger, Maria Mauricio, 31, both of Bayonne, N.J., suffered head trauma and cuts, said Todd McClendon, a spokesman for the Newark police.
The women were treated at University Hospital in Newark and released, a hospital spokesman said.

New Jersey's Transportation Department closed ramps to the roadway yesterday so crews could remove additional ice, said Erin Phalon, an agency spokeswoman. Transportation crews were also checking other overpasses and bridges in the area for ice, she said.
